argumentText:
The following proof of Radon-Nikodym theorem is based on the original
argument by John von Neumann. We suppose that $\mu$ and $\nu$ are real,
nonnegative, and finite. The extension to the $\sigma$-finite case is a
standard exercise, as is $\mu$-a.e. uniqueness of Radon-Nikodym
derivative. Having done this, the thesis also holds for signed and
complex-valued measures.

Let $(X,\mathcal{F})$ be a measurable space and let
$\mu,\nu:\mathcal{F}\to[0,R]$ two finite measures on $X$ such that
$\nu(A)=0$ for every $A\in\mathcal{F}$ such that $\mu(A)=0$. Then
$\sigma=\mu+\nu$ is a finite measure on $X$ such that $\sigma(A)=0$ if
and only if $\mu(A)=0$.

Consider the linear functional
$T:L^2(X,\mathcal{F},\sigma)\to\mathbb{R}$ defined by $$\label{eq:T}
Tu=\int_Xu\;d\mu\;\;\forall u\in L^2(X,\mathcal{F},\sigma)\;.$$ $T$ is
well-defined because $\mu$ is finite and dominated by $\sigma$, so that
$L^2(X,\mathcal{F},\sigma)
\subseteq L^2(X,\mathcal{F},\mu)
\subseteq L^1(X,\mathcal{F},\mu);$ it is also linear and bounded because
$|Tu|\leq\|u\|_{L^2(X,\mathcal{F},\sigma)}\cdot\sqrt{\sigma(X)}.$ By
Riesz representation theorem, there exists
$g\in L^2(X,\mathcal{F},\sigma)$ such that $$\label{eq:g}
Tu=\int_Xu\;d\mu=\int_Xu\cdot g\,d\sigma$$ for every
$u\in L^2(X,\mathcal{F},\sigma)$. Then $\mu(A)=\int_Ag\,d\sigma$ for
every $A\in\mathcal{F}$, so that $0<g\leq 1$ $\mu$- and $\sigma$-a.e.
(Consider the former with $A=\{x\mid g(x)\leq 0\}$ or
$A=\{x\mid g(x)>1\}$.) Moreover, the second equality in (\[eq:q\]) holds
when $u=\chi_A$ for $A\in\mathcal{F}$, thus also when $u$ is a simple
measurable function by linearity of integral, and finally when $u$ is a
($\mu$- and $\sigma$-a.e.) nonnegative $\mathcal{F}$-measurable function
because of the monotone convergence theorem.

Now, $1/g$ is $\mathcal{F}$-measurable and nonnegative $\mu$- and
$\sigma$-a.e.; moreover, $\dfrac{1}{g}\cdot g=1$ $\sigma$- and
$\mu$-a.e. Thus, for every $A\in\mathcal{F}$, $$\label{eq:1/g}
\int_A\frac{1}{g}\,d\mu
=\int_Ad\sigma
=\sigma(A)$$ Since $\sigma$ is finite, $1/g\in L^1(X,\mathcal{F},\mu)$,
and so is $f=\dfrac{1}{g}-1$. Then for every $A\in\mathcal{F}$
$$\nu(A)=\sigma(A)-\mu(A)
=\int_A\left(\frac{1}{g}-1\right)d\mu
=\int_Af\,d\mu\,.$$
